Cool, you can use regular olive oil too.

Don't be envious of what you don'=
t have, be grateful for things you already posses.  Nothing is worth more t=
han family and friends.

On Jan 16, 2012, at 6:39 PM, Super Cyclonus <super=
cyclonus@...> wrote:

> Thanks Sandy, I will have to try that. I have=
 not bee a fan of the
> extra virgin Olive Oil, but we shall see :)

> - =
Preston

> On 1/13/12, Sandy <magicquartz@...> wrote:
> > A while b=
ack I posted my famous chicken soup recipe.
> > Well, as luck would have it=
 I have again, created a rather delectable dish.
> >
> > Saut=C3=A9ed chick=
en breast with Extra Virgin olive oil, sage, garlic, lemon
> > juice and sa=
lt.
> >
> > 1: Coat a large skillet with extra virgin olive oil.
> >
> > 2:=
 peel about a half dozen cloves of garlic, and add them to the skillet.
> >=

> > 3: Bring the heat up to medium high on the stove. Once the garlic begi=
ns to
> > sizzle, lower the heat one notch on the stove. Once the garlic co=
lors
> > slightly, remove it from the skillet and put aside on another plat=
e, and
> > save it for the end of the cooking process.
> >
> > 4: while wor=
king on the garlic in the skillet, quarter three large chicken
> > breasts =
and then slice them into kabob like pieces. Once this is done, drop
> > it =
into the skillet and turn occasionally.
> >
> > 5: As the chicken cooks, pr=
epare a handful of fresh sage, and add it to the
> > chicken when it begins=
 to have a light golden color. Also re introduce the
> > garlic and add sal=
t, and lemon juice. Saut=C3=A9 until golden brown.
> >
> > And then.. ENJOY=
. ^^
> >
> >
>
